data.title: List of Jewish Nobel laureates
data.text:
Of the 965 individual recipients of the Nobel Prize and the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences between 1901 and 2023,[1] at least 214 have been Jews or people with at least one Jewish parent, representing 22% of all recipients. Jews comprise only 0.2% of the world's population, meaning their share of winners is 110 times their proportion of the world's population.[2][3][4][5]

Jews have been awarded all six of the Nobel Foundation's awards:[3]

Chemistry: 36 (19% of total)

Economics: 38 (41% of total)

Literature: 16 (13% of total)

Peace: 9 (8% of total)

Physics: 56 (25% of total)

Physiology or Medicine: 59 (26% of total)

Adolf von Baeyer, recipient of the 1905 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, was Jewish on his mother's side and is considered the first Jewish awardee.[6]

Jewish laureates Elie Wiesel and Imre Kertész survived the extermination camps during the Holocaust.[7] François Englert survived by being hidden in orphanages and children's homes.[8] Others, such as Hans Bethe, Walter Kohn, Otto Stern, Albert Einstein, Hans Krebs and Martin Karplus fled Nazi Germany to avoid persecution.[9][10][11] Still others, including Rita Levi-Montalcini, Herbert Hauptman, Robert Furchgott, Arthur Kornberg, and Jerome Karle, experienced significant antisemitism in their careers.[10][12]

Arthur Ashkin, a 96-year-old American Jew, was, at the time of his award, the oldest person to receive a Nobel Prize.[13][14]

Chemistry

[edit]

Year Laureate Country Rationale 1906 Henri Moissan[15][16][17][18][19] France "[for his] investigation and isolation of the element fluorine, and for [the] electric furnace called after him"[20] 1910 Otto Wallach[15][16][17][18] Germany "[for] his services to organic chemistry and the chemical industry by his pioneer work in the field of alicyclic compounds"[21] 1915 Richard Willstätter[15][16][17][18] Germany "for his researches on plant pigments, especially chlorophyll"[22] 1918 Fritz Haber[15][16][17][18][23] Germany "for the synthesis of ammonia from its elements"[24] 1943 George de Hevesy[15][16][17][18] Hungary "for his work on the use of isotopes as tracers in the study of chemical processes"[25] 1961 Melvin Calvin[15][16][17][18] United States "for his research on the carbon dioxide assimilation in plants"[26] 1962 Max Perutz[15][16][17][18][27] United Kingdom / Austria "for their studies of the structures of globular proteins"[28] 1972 Christian B. Brown[15][16][18][33] United States / United Kingdom "for their development of the use of boron- and phosphorus-containing compounds, respectively, into important reagents in organic synthesis"[34] 1980 Paul Berg[15][16][18][35] United States "for his fundamental studies of the biochemistry of nucleic acids, with particular regard to recombinant-DNA"[36] Walter Gilbert[15][16][18] "for their contributions concerning the determination of base sequences in nucleic acids"[36] 1981 Roald Hoffmann[15][16][18] United States / Poland / Ukraine "for their theories, developed independently, concerning the course of chemical reactions"[37] 1982 Aaron Klug[15][16][18] United Kingdom / South Africa / Lithuania "for his development of crystallographic electron microscopy and his structural elucidation of biologically important nucleic acid-protein complexes"[38] 1985 Jerome Karle[12][15][16][18][39][40] United States "for their outstanding achievements in developing direct methods for the determination of crystal structures"[41] Herbert A. Hauptman[10][15][16][18][42][43] 1986 John Polanyi[44] Hungary / Canada / Germany "for his work in chemical kinetics.[44] 1989 Sidney Altman[15][16][18] Canada / United States "for their discovery of catalytic properties of RNA"[45] 1992 Rudolph A. Marcus[15][16][18] United States / Canada "for his contributions to the theory of electron transfer reactions in chemical systems"[46] 1994 George Andrew Olah[47][15][18] United States / Hungary "for his contribution to carbocation chemistry"[48] 1996 Harry Kroto[18][49] United Kingdom "for the discovery of fullerenes"[50] 1998 Walter Kohn[9][10][15][18][51] United States / Austria "for his development of the density-functional theory"[52] 2000 Alan J. Physics

[edit]

Year Laureate Country Rationale 1907 Albert A. Michelson[16][17][146] United States / Germany / Poland "for his optical precision instruments and the spectroscopic and metrological investigations carried out with their aid"[147] 1908 Gabriel Lippmann[16][17][146] France / Luxemburg "for his method of reproducing colours photographically based on the phenomenon of interference"[148] 1921 Albert Einstein[16][17][146][149] Germany / Switzerland "for his services to Theoretical Physics, and especially for his discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect"[150] 1922 Niels Bohr[16][17][146][149] Denmark "for his services in the investigation of the structure of atoms and of the radiation emanating from them"[151] 1925 James Franck[16][146] Germany "for their discovery of the laws governing the impact of an electron upon an atom"[152] Gustav Hertz[16][17] 1943 Otto Stern[16][146] United States / Germany "for his contribution to the development of the molecular ray method and his discovery of the magnetic moment of the proton"[153] 1944 Isidor Isaac Rabi[16][17][146] United States / Austria-Hungary / Poland "for his resonance method for recording the magnetic properties of atomic nuclei"[154] 1945 Wolfgang Pauli[146][155] Austria / United States "for the discovery of the Exclusion Principle, also called the Pauli principle"[156] 1952 Felix Bloch[16][17][146] United States / Switzerland "for their development of new methods for nuclear magnetic precision measurements and discoveries in connection therewith"[157] 1954 Max Born[16][17][146] United Kingdom / Germany "for his fundamental research in quantum mechanics, especially for his statistical interpretation of the wavefunction"[158] 1958 Ilya Frank[146][159] Soviet Union "for the discovery and the interpretation of the Cherenkov effect"[160] Igor Tamm[16][17][146][159][161] 1959 Emilio Gino Segrè[16][17][146] Italy / United States "for their discovery of the antiproton"[162] 1960 Donald A. Literature

[edit]

Year Laureate Country Rationale 1910 Paul Heyse[47][222] Germany "as a tribute to the consummate artistry, permeated with idealism, which he has demonstrated during his long productive career as a lyric poet, dramatist, novelist and writer of world-renowned short stories"[223] 1927 Henri Bergson[222] France "in recognition of his rich and vitalizing ideas and the brilliant skill with which they have been presented"[224] 1958 Boris Pasternak[222] Soviet Union "for his important achievement both in contemporary lyrical poetry and in the field of the great Russian epic tradition"[225] 1966 Shmuel Yosef Agnon[222] Israel / Poland / Ukraine "for his profoundly characteristic narrative art with motifs from the life of the Jewish people"[226] Nelly Sachs[222] Sweden / Germany "for her outstanding lyrical and dramatic writing, which interprets Israel's destiny with touching strength"[226] 1976 Saul Bellow[222] United States / Canada "for the human understanding and subtle analysis of contemporary culture that are combined in his work"[227] 1978 Isaac Bashevis Singer[222] United States / Poland "for his impassioned narrative art which, with roots in a Polish-Jewish cultural tradition, brings universal human conditions to life"[228] 1981 Elias Canetti[222] United Kingdom / Bulgaria "for writings marked by a broad outlook, a wealth of ideas and artistic power"[229] 1987 Joseph Brodsky[222] United States / Soviet Union "for an all-embracing authorship, imbued with clarity of thought and poetic intensity"[230] 1991 Nadine Gordimer[222] South Africa "who through her magnificent epic writing has – in the words of Alfred Nobel – been of very great benefit to humanity"[231] 2002 Imre Kertész[222][232][233] Hungary "for writing that upholds the fragile experience of the individual against the barbaric arbitrariness of history"[234] 2004 Elfriede Jelinek[235] Austria "for her musical flow of voices and counter-voices in novels and plays that with extraordinary linguistic zeal reveal the absurdity of society's clichés and their subjugating power"[236] 2005 Harold Pinter[222][237] United Kingdom "who in his plays uncovers the precipice under everyday prattle and forces entry into oppression's closed rooms"[238] 2014 Patrick Modiano[239]

[240]

France "for the art of memory with which he has evoked the most ungraspable human destinies and uncovered the life-world of the occupation"[241] 2016 Bob Dylan[242][243] United States "for having created new poetic expressions within the great American song tradition" 2020 Louise Glück[244][245][246] United States "for her unmistakable poetic voice that with austere beauty makes individual existence universal."[247]

[edit]

Year Laureate Country Rationale 1970 Paul Samuelson[248][249] United States "for the scientific work through which he has developed static and dynamic economic theory and actively contributed to raising the level of analysis in economic science"[250] 1971 Simon Kuznets[248][251] United States / Russia "for his empirically founded interpretation of economic growth which has led to new and deepened insight into the economic and social structure and process of development"[252] 1976 Milton Friedman[248][253][257] United States "for his achievements in the fields of consumption analysis, monetary history and theory and for his demonstration of the complexity of stabilization policy"[258] 1978 Herbert A. Merton[273] United States 2001 Joseph Stiglitz[248][259] United States "for their analyses of markets with asymmetric information"[274] George Akerlof[275] 2002 Daniel Kahneman[248][259] Israel / United States "for having integrated insights from psychological research into economic science, especially concerning human judgment and decision-making under uncertainty"[276] 2005 Robert Aumann[248][277] Israel / United States / Germany "for having enhanced our understanding of conflict and cooperation through game-theory analysis"[278] 2007 Leonid Hurwicz[248][279][280][281][282] United States / Poland / Russia "for having laid the foundations of mechanism design theory"[283] Eric Maskin[248][282][284] United States Roger Myerson[248][282] 2008 Paul Krugman[248][285] United States "for his analysis of trade patterns and location of economic activity"[286] 2009 Elinor Ostrom[287][288] United States "for her analysis of economic governance, especially the commons"[289] 2010 Peter Diamond[290][291] United States "for his analysis of markets with search frictions"[292] 2012 Alvin E. Roth[293] United States "for the theory of stable allocations and the practice of market design"[294] 2016 Oliver Hart[295] United States / United Kingdom "contributions to contract theory" 2017 Richard Thaler[296] United States "contributions have built a bridge between the economic and psychological analyses of individual decision-making" 2018 William Nordhaus[297][298] United States "for integrating climate change into long-run macroeconomic analysis"[299] 2019 Michael Kremer[300] United States "for their experimental approach to alleviating global poverty" 2020 Paul Milgrom[301][302][303] United States "for improvements to auction theory and inventions of new auction formats"[304] 2021 Joshua Angrist[305][306][307] United States / Israel "for their methodological contributions to the analysis of causal relationships"[308] 2022 Ben Bernanke[309][310][311] United States "for research on banks and financial crises"[312] 2022 Douglas Diamond[313] 2023 Claudia Goldin[314] United States "for having advanced our understanding of women's labour market outcomes".[315]

[edit]

Year Laureate Country Rationale 1911 Tobias Michael Carel Asser[316] Netherlands "Initiator of the Conferences on International Private Law at the Hague; Cabinet Minister; Lawyer"[317] Alfred Hermann Fried[318] Austria "Journalist; Founder of Die Friedenswarte"[317] 1968 René Cassin[319][320][321] France "President of the European Court for Human Rights"[322] 1973 Henry A. Kissinger[323] United States / Germany "For the 1973 Paris agreement intended to bring about a cease-fire in the Vietnam War and a withdrawal of the American forces"[324][325] 1978 Menachem Begin[326] Israel / Russia / Poland "for the Camp David Agreement, which brought about a negotiated peace between Egypt and Israel"[327] 1986 Elie Wiesel[328] United States / Romania "Chairman of "The President's Commission on the Holocaust""[329] 1994 Yitzhak Rabin[330] Israel "to honour a political act which called for great courage on both sides, and which has opened up opportunities for a new development towards fraternity in the Middle East."[331] Shimon Peres[332] Israel / Poland 1995 Joseph Rotblat[333][334][335] Poland / United Kingdom "for his efforts to diminish the part played by nuclear arms in international politics and, in the longer run, to eliminate such arms"[336]

Forced to decline prize

[edit]

Year Laureate Country Rationale 1958 Boris Pasternak USSR Literature: "for his notable achievement in both contemporary poetry and the field of the great Russian narrative tradition".[337] Pasternak initially accepted the award, but—after intense pressure from Soviet authorities—subsequently declined it.[338][339][340][341]

Jewish laureates per country

[edit]

Below is a chart of all Jewish Nobel laureates per country (updated to 2022 laureates). Some laureates are counted more than once if have multiple citizenship.

Country Number of Jewish Nobel laureates United States 132 Germany 29 United Kingdom 20 Russia/Soviet Union 14 Israel 13 Poland 11 Austria 10 France 10 Hungary 9 Canada 6 Switzerland 5 Ukraine 5 South Africa 4 Italy 4 Denmark 3 Belgium 2 Lithuania 1 Bulgaria 1 Morocco 1 Venezuela 1 Luxemburg 1 Algeria 1 Belarus 1 Romania 1 Argentina 1 Czechia 1 Netherlands 1 Sweden 1

Nobel Laureates Boulevard

[edit]

The Israeli city of Rishon LeZion has an avenue dedicated to honoring all Jewish Nobel laureates. The street, called Tayelet Hatanei Pras Nobel (Nobel Laureates Boulevard/Promenade), has a monument with attached plaque for each Nobel laureate. The scientific adviser of the project was Prof. Israel Hanukoglu.[342]
